SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: CRISTAL FERN HACKETT

Present Address: GAINSBOURG SASK.

Pioneer Address: GAINSBOURG ASSINIBOIA.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1892.

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Just a few.

   How many of these were bachelor's homes? Not many.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Not too often.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Both.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without a invitation, and we would.

   What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? In the morning, afternoon, evening.

   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, sometimes.

5. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

   You might say, "I'm glad you came on time to get your name in the pot."

   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Possibly a cup of tea or coffee and something to eat.

6. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Mostly the whole family.

7. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? For the women.

   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

8. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

   Write a number of parties, mostly played games and some time danced.

   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. No.

9. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
1. In the first few years, how many hours were made available to you for visiting? How many of these were bachelor parties? What was the purpose?

2. How often did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? — hour to 5 p.m.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? — both

4. Have you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Write out a list of reasons why.

That time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day or in the afternoon, etc.? In the morning, afternoon, evening, night?

5. Did you stay then not invited beforehand? Yes, sometimes.

6. Was there an invitation to a meal, whether when people had come unexpectedly (not as a result of a formal dinner party), or was some other expression common? Yes, was the same to invite dinner guests, or was some other expression used?

7. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had wandered in? A beverage, a cup of tea or coffee?

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the plants"?

9. Did you ever have "parties" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a billboard, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what they were for, and how often they occurred.

10. Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. — no.

11. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

The school was used for dances, box socials, and picnics.

For dances held in fall 1944 and also non-socially

Picnics before 1944 were held in our own grounds.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Most of it, with town and

Too far away for the house or buggy stops.

3. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?).

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What games were popular?

Square Dances, Waltzes, etc.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Some did not believe in dancing, so games were played.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the house, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Playing cards were not popular as a rule. They were frowned upon by quite a number.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

There wasn't any formality in the country, but some in the small towns, such as calling cards, gloves and hats.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? The Epworth League.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

The reason for organizing this society was for a social hour and a religious meeting.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Yes

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality, or "newness," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visiting treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were.

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any plans or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

16. Was there a Shaptechean Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1930, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? - Concerts and fairs

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? - School house

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? - Yes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? - Yes Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? - Roll and go stick, Pull away

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? - Games same as the boys

That games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play houses, etc.)?

and games done on the boat.
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Snowballing.

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   Mostly busy.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   (Snowy gophers)

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?  
   The Community.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   Yes.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   Yes.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Yes.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   No.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Practically everything today.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   After dinner till dark.

There was races for young folk, swings for the children, a tall pole between usually a small booth where cotton candy peanuts popcorn were sold and also lemonade.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

There are very few county picnics now and not as much social activity. She can take people away to the town for other amusements.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

There never was a rink and some skating was done on the creek in January. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.
